title: 106_s1898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Interstate Transportation of Dangerous Criminals Act of 2000" or "Jeanna's Act." Congress finds that States are increasingly using private prisoner transport companies for violent prisoners, leading to escapes and the need for oversight by the Attorney General. While most prefer law enforcement officers, fiscal or logistical concerns may necessitate the use of specialized private transport companies. Private prisoner transport companies may be used due to fiscal or logistical concerns, but if they are used for moving violent prisoners, they should be regulated to ensure public safety. The Act defines key terms such as "crime of violence," "private prisoner transport company," and "violent prisoner." Federal regulation of prisoner transport companies. The Attorney General, in consultation with relevant organizations, will establish regulations for transporting violent prisoners across state lines. These regulations will cover background checks, drug testing, and training requirements for employees of prisoner transport companies. Minimum standards for training employees in transporting prisoners include up to 100 hours of preservice training covering restraints, searches, use of force, CPR, map reading, and defensive driving. Restrictions on employee duty hours must comply with federal regulations. Standards for supervising violent prisoners should allow for discretion by the transport entity. Minimum standards for supervising violent prisoners include requirements for employee uniforms, identification, clothing, and restraints. Private prisoner transport companies must notify local law enforcement when transporting violent prisoners. The regulations for private prisoner transport companies include requirements for double-locked handcuffs, advance notification to local law enforcement for transporting violent prisoners, immediate notification in case of escape, and minimum safety standards for violent prisoners. Federal standards do not include subsection (b)(6) requirements. The regulations for private prisoner transport companies must comply with Federal and State law, with exceptions for stricter standards compared to the United States Marshals Service, Federal Bureau of Prisons, and Immigration and Naturalization Service when transporting violent prisoners. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT. Any person violating regulations under this Act may face a civil penalty up to $10,000 per violation, along with prosecution costs. They must also reimburse entities for expenses related to apprehending escaped violent prisoners due to regulation violations.
